name: politico
text: The presidential election will be won or lost in these 8 swing states. Welcome to the 2020 battlegrounds. üëá https://t.co/VR1OfT1VvJ

name: politico
text:
1Ô∏è‚É£ Wisconsin
In  2016, Trump unexpectedly took the state by fewer than 23,000 votes and every expectation is that it will be a nail-biter again in November. Republicans insist Biden and his party have failed to learn from the mistakes of four years ago. https://t.co/cpEMBp26eJ

name: politico
text:
2Ô∏è‚É£ Minnesota
This is the rare offensive opportunity for Trump on a battleground map that has him mostly on defense. Sept. 18's early voting, will offer one of the first tests of whether he can turn out enough white, working class voters to expand his base https://t.co/a4d0K2D48o

name: politico
text:
3Ô∏è‚É£ North Carolina
It‚Äôs the ‚Äúswingiest of swing states‚Äù and white, college-educated, unaffiliated suburban women still making up their mind as Election Day looms can make or break the race for either candidate https://t.co/qzKVzvK6Tt

name: politico
text:
4Ô∏è‚É£ Arizona
Migration from California, a growing Latino population, and shifting attitudes among white college-educated voters are reshaping the state‚Äôs political landscape, giving it a new status as a true battleground  https://t.co/RwNRGWtlbY

name: politico
text:
5Ô∏è‚É£ Georgia
The prospect of turning Georgia blue for the first time since 1992 is a stretch, Dems will need something close to a blowout win in the Atlanta suburbs and a surge in Black voter turnout. But after significant steps in 2018, it is a possibility. https://t.co/nxz8INPe9s

name: politico
text:
6Ô∏è‚É£ Michigan
Trump won Michigan in 2016 by a total of just 10,704 votes out of some 4.7 million cast. Every conceivable thing broke his way. But the conditions that enabled the president‚Äôs lightning-in-a-bottle 2016 victory appear to be missing this year. https://t.co/rZmEG3qyIi

name: politico
text:
7Ô∏è‚É£ Florida
Biden has a marginal lead right now. And, for the first time in at least a decade, Dems cast more primary ballots than the GOP in the state. Yet Dems are haunted by the uneasy feeling that Trump will win anyway in November. https://t.co/K3kfoPBFwO

name: politico
text:
8Ô∏è‚É£ Pennsylvania
Joe Biden has beaten Donald Trump in nearly every public poll in Pennsylvania this year. Still, almost everyone on both sides expects another squeaker like in 2016, when Trump took Pennsylvania in 2016 by an eyelash https://t.co/KPSObhk0uz

text: Both parties largely have agreed for months that K-12 schools and colleges need more federal assistance to help them grapple with the health care crisis. But that funding hasn‚Äôt materialized amid a stalemate over the next relief package https://t.co/Qvb7NxLGxW

name: politico
text: The Senate returns today from August recess, and Republicans are expected to hold a vote this week on a scaled-back aid bill that includes $105 billion in funding for schools https://t.co/Qvb7NxLGxW

name: politico
text: The other major to-do for Congress in the coming weeks is to fund the government, including the Education Department, for some amount of time beyond the end of the 2020 fiscal year on Sept. 30 https://t.co/Qvb7NxLGxW

name: politico
text: And fights drag on over how the Education Department is distributing money from the CARES Act, which passed in March https://t.co/Qvb7NxLGxW

name: politico
text: Nearly all of the roughly $30B for education under the bill has been legally promised to states and colleges to help with the pandemic. But only about $8.3B  has actually been paid out, according to the most recent federal spending records  https://t.co/Qvb7NxLGxW

name: politico
text: Meanwhile, on K-12 education funding, the Education Department will have to respond to a major court ruling from Friday night that struck down its plan to boost funding to private school students https://t.co/Qvb7NxLGxW
